channel.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
channel.description:

revolution leads to resignation of Hosni Mubarak

item.description:

Thug-life:

http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/13/egypt-military-rejects-swift-power-handover

Thank god. That way - I hope - Hosni’s party won’t be able to grab what they can before elections.

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Frell:

Apparently the person some Egyptians are talking about for office now is anti American and anti Israel. Forgot his name though

It has been a worry to the Americans that the next person put in office would be anti-american and anti-israel since the protests started.

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:16, topic:382123”][quote author=Frell link=topic=477923.msg3499149#msg3499149 date=1297598313]

Feels weird. This is one of the first ever events in my lifetime that I feel will be studied in depth in History lessons in 75 years time, aside from the afghan/iraq wars.

And by then we might know the actual motive behind the wars that stirred up a pretty solid coalition.

Apparently the person some Egyptians are talking about for office now is anti American and anti Israel. Forgot his name though
[/quote]

Maybe one time, just one time, you can set your own preferences aside and let the people decide for themselves.[/quote]To be fair, Frell did not express his opinion there at all!

Read full topic

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:9, topic:382123”][quote author=TheBeanie link=topic=477923.msg3498244#msg3498244 date=1297518395]
Yea, Now the country is being run by the military, I don’t really think that’s a better thing to run the country.
[/quote]

Actually so far the military seems pretty good, and they have vowed to put a democratic government in place, so as long as they keep their promises there shouldn’t be any problems. Good for Egypt, hopefully this spreads throughout the rest of the world.[/quote]

In this case, the military seems the only decent solution. Mubarak was almost completely right: It was either him or chaos, he said. He should have mentioned the military too. Thing is though, the military basically runs the economy. The military is the economy. So I wonder if they keep their promises and organize fair elections soon.

Read full topic

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

TheBeanie:

Yea, Now the country is being run by the military, I don’t really think that’s a better thing to run the country.

Actually so far the military seems pretty good, and they have vowed to put a democratic government in place, so as long as they keep their promises there shouldn’t be any problems. Good for Egypt, hopefully this spreads throughout the rest of the world.

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:6, topic:382123”]Well if that’s the case then whatever. Some people are too dangerous to be kept alive though.
A case in point would be Kim Jong Il. The world would be better off without him.[/quote]

An assassination would be a good way to get rid of a dictator, but killing someone when he has lost all his power is pointless.

Read full topic

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @Thebeanie TheBeanie
item.description:

item.title: Hosni Mubarak resigns
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:5, topic:382123”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=477923.msg3497563#msg3497563 date=1297463230]
They should kill him for good measure. Just like the French did in their revolution.
[/quote]

Why kill him? What good does that do? He doesn’t have any power anymore, his Swiss bank accounts are frozen, and he’ll die in a few years anyways. He should be tried by an Egyptian court and spend his last years in prison.[/quote]
Well if that’s the case then whatever. Some people are too dangerous to be kept alive though.
A case in point would be Kim Jong Il. The world would be better off without him.

Read full topic
